1_1K94YiuAXaLsup6mn1FPMCxZanFt7CBjAT.body: I used Ruby for an internship once . . . never again.  That shit is terrible.

> eelelo: Python for prototyping. 

Python for anything less than 100 lines of code that you don't have to maintain and which needs to call multiple C/C++ libraries.  Otherwise the maintenance burden is too high.

> eelelo: Go for micro services. 

If you enjoy using 1970s technology in 2017, who are we to stop you?  But the whole point of "microservices" (or what we used to call "modular design") is that it doesn't matter as much whether you choose Rob Pike's blast-from-the-past or anything else.

> eelelo: Java for larger projects. 

Well, your memory footprint alone will guarantee it's a "larger project" if you use the JVM.  Personally I'd lean towards something with a more useful type system like OCaml or Haskell.  

The JVM's garbage collector is a work of art, though, and the debugging tools are great, but that doesn't outweigh the pain of writing enough Java to need either of those features in my experience.

> eelelo: C for embedded.

For now.  Hopefully things like Rust and ATS are the future in the embedded space.

First, let's look at some qualifiers -- not the reason I put it in quotes, but informative context (from Wikipedia):

> In all known cases, speakers are natively bilingual, or multilingual, raised in both Esperanto and either the local national language or the native language of their parents. In all but a handful of cases, it was the father who used Esperanto with the child. In the majority of such families, the parents had the same native language, though in many the parents had different native languages, and only Esperanto in common.

So for all of these speakers, it's _one_ of multiple first languages.

But actually, I put it in quotes for a more subtle reason I should have explained.  Typically when the children of pidgin-speakers learn language, they speak differently from their parents.  The saying is that "adults create pidgins, and children create creoles."  I hadn't found documentation on this when I wrote my other message, but I strongly suspected that true native speakers of constructed languages perform the same creolization process and "normalize" the constructed language into a natural one.  Now that you brought it up, I looked into it, and behold (again, from Wikipedia):

> The Esperanto of native-speaking children differs from the standard Esperanto spoken by their parents. In some cases this is due to interference from their other native language (the adstrate), but in others it appears to be an effect of acquisition.

The article goes on with some specific examples.  Constructed languages present a bit of a conundrum in this case: who is speaking the "real" Esperanto?  Constructed languages are, in theory, explicitly defined (not all that explicitly, in some parts of Esperanto), so if the children deviate from this definition, they're speaking something slightly different to Esperanto.  But the parents aren't native speakers, so aren't children speaking "true" Esperanto?

This ambiguity is what I was trying to capture with the quotes.

> [krixano](#comment_53_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): According to the study, it does get you faster. People who spend 1 year with esperanto then 3 with french knew more than people with 4 years of french. This also means that you would have learned what the people with 4 years of french learned in less than 3 years. That's mathematics - simple. 

If only language learning were that simple!  If the study's results hold generally, it means you got to the "4 years of French" proficiency level faster; it doesn't show that you get to fluency any faster.  Language learning is, sadly, not a simple linear process.  In other domains of learning, these sorts of transient effects show up at certain stages and then disappear when long-term outcomes are measured.

But I'm also skeptical because I don't know how much stock to put in your and Wikipedia's summary of the results of the study.  I'd feel more certain if I could read the study and see exactly what they claim and what their data show.  There are several studies linked in the article, but I don't know how to get articles from those journals and books for free, and I'm not going to pay through the nose to justify myself in an internet forum :)

> [krixano](#comment_53_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): This also means you can explore the literature sooner since you would be knowing more sooner.

It's unfortunate again, but this does not mean you can explore the literature sooner; let's say you want to watch a French movie after two years of study.  If you have been studying French, you can probably understand a lot of it and follow what's going on.  If you've been studying Esperanto, you'll get very little out of it.  The two-year figure is arbitrary; the point is that if you want to use French any time in the first 3 years of study for something you find cool or rewarding or useful, you'd better not have been spending all of that time on Esperanto.

> [krixano](#comment_53_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): You don't think that a grammar that has consistent endings like what esperanto has (o for noun, a for adjective, etc.) is easier than trying to learn all the different conjugates of other languages, especially Spanish and Latin? Esperanto verbs don't conjugate based on person or number, but Spanish ones do, which means there are more endings for Spanish. You don't think that because of this Esperanto verbs would be easier to learn and remember?

I've said nothing of the sort!  Counting noun and verb endings is a crude measure of how easy it is to learn a language, and for this, like probably any specific feature of a language you can think of, the "difficulty" depends on which languages the learner is already familiar with (by way of example, Mandarin has no noun or pronoun declensions or verb conjugations).  I suppose I'll just have to start repeating what I've already said several times in the thread: even if it's easier, it doesn't mean learning it is time well spent.

By the way, I'm curious to know your opinion of this (hilarious if a bit overstated) site: http://jbr.me.uk/ranto/

> [krixano](#comment_54_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): I didn't say that Esperanto itself was easier because of those particular ending, only that those ending would be easier to remember than a ton of different endings used in Spanish, Latin, and other similar languages. 

I totally agree it's easier to remember fewer endings; I just don't know whether that means anything significant when it comes to actually learning the whole language.

> [krixano](#comment_54_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): Also, you better not be spending all that time on Esperanto makes no sense because I have already stated that it's only 1 year of Esperanto. You're not spending 4 years on Esperanto, only 1, then 3 on French.

Thanks for the correction -- I repeatedly misread your message as "3 of Esperanto followed by 1 of French."  We still don't know whether you're ahead or behind at the 2-year mark.

> [krixano](#comment_54_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): Now, technically neither of us have proved that it is/isn't worth it. I think it is, you don't. Let's just leave it at that. I'm not going to try to convince you when there are studies you can look at for yourself.

I guess I mentioned that I can't currently find a way to look at them, which makes me sad.  But in any case, if you're done, I want to thank you for an interesting discussion.  I learned some things and had a good time, which is better than I can say about 99% of zeronet discussions!  XD

[krixano](#comment_55_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): I didn't mean to be rude with that last paragraph. I now realize how that might have sounded. 

No harm done; it's an internet forum . . .

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propaedeutic_value_of_Esperanto  describes several studies.  The summaries there are generally encouraging, and several studies indicate that people can generally learn Esperanto faster than natural languages, but there's not too much specific information about the question we were discussing (the degree to which Esperanto preparation accelerates learning of other languages), and it seems like some of the studies may not be very well conducted.  I'll try to summarize a bit:

>  after having compared the French exercises of those children who had previously studied Esperanto with those who had not received such preliminary preparation, indications as to the introductory value of the International Language were reached.

Seems like they found that learning Esperanto before French helped, but they didn't compare to learning any other language first, so it's more of a comparison of second- to third-language learning.

> the unchallenged superiority in the ability to use German achieved by the students who had studied Esperanto was observed;

Same problem, as far as I can make out -- they only compared it to not studying anything first.

>  In summary, it was concluded that, among the less intelligent students, those who devoted a year to Esperanto succeeded better in French after four years, without additional study time for that language in the three years spent studying it.  In any case, among the more intelligent students, the best success in French was among those who began it immediately. Those who began with Esperanto achieved a better "passive knowledge" and those who began with French acquired better "active use."

This study seems similar to those above and the one you mentioned, but they find an effect that depends on "intelligence."  Without more detail, it's hard to see how they measured this (many classic pitfalls there, obviously), but if we accept it, it's still only comparing second-language learning to third-language learning.

There are some non-quantitative comments I found interesting:

> the rapid results achieved in Esperanto instruction raised the students' courage and their faith in themselves; the capacity to accept new ways in which to express themselves already constitutes a help, at the subconscious level, in assimilating a new foreign language.

This alone seems potentially valuable, especially for students who are unmotivated, reluctant or otherwise not inclined to apply themselves to their studies.

> contribute to a European childhood education and a humanistic internationalism.
> very quickly creates the possibility of interethnic communication perfect for children, without limiting it to the territory of a specific privileged language. In such a way it opens the way to better comprehension between people, without language discrimination.
> The Esperanto-pupils rated LOTE-learning and also rated Esperanto one of their favourite subjects [if I read into it that other pupils were surveyed and did not do so]

These are all interesting effects.  But what I'd really like to see is an experiment that compares preparatory study in Esperanto to preparatory study in other languages, ideally several so there's some idea of how much variation to expect and possibly some information on how linguistic distance plays into things.  For example, you could have English-speaking students do preparatory study in French, Esperanto, Latin, Russian or nothing, and then measure how it affects their performance at learning Spanish and Arabic later on.  It seems like right now we just don't have enough evidence to say anything conclusive about this question.

> [helium](#comment_12_1Pv5CdXMDJm5k5iAp4SVbutnMg2ue8e58p): I find the matrix.org to be analogous to the ZeroNet in at least 2 ways: [...]

Thanks for your thoughtful reply.

I fully agree about similarity number one.  Sadly, this also means matrix.org struggles to make ends meet.  I haven't tried Diaspora, but I'm more than willing to believe that it's difficult for your average user to set up.

Regarding similarity #2, for matrix, there is actually no strict requirement at the moment; it's actually possible to chat/VOIP/etc. using matrix.org as your homeserver via the riot.im web client, with no node setup yourself.  Your preferences, history etc. are all stored on matrix.org at no charge (maybe this is why they are having financial difficulty . . . ;); end-to-end encryption works as well as possible in your browser.  But yes, the intended use case is for you to run your own homeserver.

I think you're dead-on regarding software quality and deadlines.  A lot of these projects, even if they begin with a good technical idea, don't seem to have looked around at prior or contemporary work and carefully thought through the design at all levels, even if they're working at their own pace.  Again I agree that this is doubly true when VCs are cracking the whip and demanding users or ad revenue by last Wednesday.  The Matrix crew seem to be doing better than most.  Hopefully they can withstand their current financial hardship long enough for their attention to detail and sound design sense to win out in this space.

Even if they do succeed in obsoleting a host of technically inferior networks, the question remains whether any such open protocol, developed by a small not-for-profit organization, will remain dominant when companies like Google or Facebook can pour money into embracing and extending it like Google did with XMPP.  When the protocol is open, there are always lots of implementations of servers and clients, and big organizations with other sources of funding (hard to make money from ads by hosting services for a federated network with an open protocol!) can typically make sure their implementations work correctly with cutting-edge features much faster than small organizations like matrix.org or random developers of other popular implementations.  The upshot is then that the majority of users stay within the walls laid out by the big organizations when told to do so, and their new features work.  At this point, most of them will not care whether the protocol is open or well-designed, and the trap is sprung.  Fingers crossed that this doesn't happen!
